newsitem.title: HONG KONG: FOCUS - Telecoms deal market reaction mixed.
newsitem.headline: FOCUS - Telecoms deal market reaction mixed.

text.p: A deal to build the world's longest and largest-capacity submarine cable network that will usher in a new era for the telecommunications industry received a mixed reaction in Asian stock markets on Thursday.
Analysts hailed the deal as one that will satisfy in future years the ever-growing demand for phone lines, including the Internet and business needs such as tele-conferencing.
It will be built by 90 of the world's top telecommunications companies and create a network stretching from the South Pacific to the North Atlantic across Asia and the Middle East.
But on Thursday, investors failed to show much interest.
Shares of Singapore Telecommunications Ltd (SingTel), which announced the U.S.$1.3 billion deal on Wednesday, ended off S$0.04 at S$3.18 in light trading.
Japan's Kokusai Densin Denwa (KDD), ended 120 yen higher at 7,570 yen, while Indonesia's Indosat gained 150 rupiah to 6,975.

"After the completion of investment plans on submarine fibre cables connecting Japan and the U.S., they've finally turned to Asia, where construction of trunk lines is relatively delayed," said Hironori Tanaka, an analyst at Yamaichi Research Institute in in Tokyo.

But in Malaysia, Telekom Malaysia fell 0.40 cents, to 20.60 ringgit as investors focused on an investigation by the government into a contract given to Sweden's LM Ericsson rather than the telecommunications deal.
"There's not much positive sentiment over the cable deal, as it's very long term," said Phuah Lee Kerk, telecommunications analyst at Vickers Ballas in Kuala Lumpur.
"Telekom will probably not see any profits from the deal for at least another three to four years," he added.
Shares of India's Videsh Sanchar Nigam Ltd (VSNL) fell 47 rupees to 942 rupees on the National Stock exchange.
Analysts said there could be more interest in the stocks on Friday since some details on associated contracts, albeit brief, was released late on Thursday.
A SingTel spokesman said contracts to build the 23,000 km (14,300 miles) stretch of cable from Singapore to Europe via the Middle East and North Africa would be worth US$720 million.
This network would be built by a consortium of KDD-Submarine Cable Systems, a unit of Japan's KDD, AT&T Submarine Cable Systems Inc, France's Alcatel and Maristel SpA of Italy.
A second stretch from Singapore to Australia, awarded to Japan's Fujitsu, would be worth US$80 million.
The SingTel spokesman said contracts to build a third part of the network, between Singapore and various Asian countries including China and Japan, had not yet been awarded.
